messageBody:
## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-06-29T17:42:28Z
## Message ID: 20180629-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

This is an update to the notifications with Activity ID 2018-06-27T17:20:00-RBE-001 (notifications 20180627-AL-001 and 20180627-AL-002).

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux continues to be elevated and close to the threshold of 10^5 pfu, currently at 98600 pfu.

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by the high speed stream starting at 2018-06-26T05:30Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2018-06-27T17:20:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes: 



NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for June 20, 2018 - June 26, 2018
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-06-27T21:46:10Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2018-06-20T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2018-06-26T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20180627-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period. There were no significant flares or CMEs.    


Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp=5 occurred during the synoptic period of 2018-06-26T21:00Z-24:00Z and continuing into the following reporting period of 2018-06-27T00:00Z-03:00Z. This slight increase in geomagnetic activity was associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 around 2018-06-26. Solar wind speed reached values of ~600 km/s on 2018-06-26.

DSCOVR/ACE at L1 also detected the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2018-06-23. Solar wind speed reached values of ~500 km/s on 2018-06-24.


The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

 
The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 


Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.



##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  


CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed   

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2018-06-27T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2018-07-03T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week. There are several active regions present on the solar disk that have some potential for flares or CMEs. Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week. The greater than 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux at the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES 13 has crossed the threshold of 10^5 pfu at 2018-06-27T17:20Z and is expected to remain elevated for a few days (see notifications 20180627-AL-001 and 20180627-AL-002).


## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux is above 10^5 pfu starting at 2018-06-27T17:20Z. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by the high speed stream starting at 2018-06-26T05:30Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for June 13, 2018 - June 19, 2018
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-06-20T19:36:14Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2018-06-13T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2018-06-19T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20180620-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

  
Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period. There were no significant flares or CMEs.    


Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp=5 occurred during the synoptic period of 2018-06-18T00:00Z-03:00Z. This slight increase in geomagnetic activity was associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 around 2018-06-17. Solar wind speed reached values of ~500 km/s on 2018-06-18 and 2018-06-19.


STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC instruments detected the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2018-06-18. Solar wind speed reached values of ~650 km/s on 2018-06-19.


The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 


The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 


Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2018-06-26T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week. There are several active regions present on the solar disk that have some potential for flares or CMEs. Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week due to the expected arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2018-06-23.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for June 06, 2018 - June 12, 2018
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-06-13T20:41:49Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2018-06-06T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2018-06-12T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20180613-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period. There were no significant flares or CMEs.     

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period.

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt were above the threshold level of 10^5 pfu at the beginning of the reporting period on 2018-06-06. This was a continuation of the radiation belt enhancement that started on 2018-06-01T18:50Z. This elevation of the energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES 13 was associated with the coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 around 2018-05-31. On 2018-06-07 the fluxes decreased and had remained at nominal levels for the rest of the reporting period.

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.  

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2018-06-13T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2018-06-19T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week. There are several active regions present at the solar surface that can produce flare and CME activity. Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week due to the expected arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2018-06-19.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for May 30, 2018 - June 05, 2018
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-06-06T21:39:06Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2018-05-30T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2018-06-05T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20180606-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period. There were no significant flares or CMEs.     

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp=5 occurred during the synoptic period of 2018-06-01T12:00Z-15:00Z. This slight increase in geomagnetic activity was associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 around 2018-05-31. Solar wind speed reached values of >750 km/s on 2018-06-01 and 2018-06-03.

The >0.8 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 10^5 pfu starting at 2018-06-01T18:50Z and remained elevated for the entire reporting period. These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES 13 were associated with the coronal hole high speed stream described above (see notifications 20180601-AL-001, 20180601-AL-002, 20180603-AL-001 and 20180605-AL-001).

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the elevated energetic electron flux on the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed   

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2018-06-06T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2018-06-12T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week. There are a few active regions currently visible at the surface of the sun that could produce some flare or CME activity. Geomagnetic activity is expected to stay elevated at the beginning of the reporting period due to the high speed stream described above. Currently, the energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt is still elevated above the threshold of 10^5 pfu. 
  
## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Continued Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-06-05T15:11:44Z
## Message ID: 20180605-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux continues to be above or near 10^5 pfu starting at 2018-06-01T18:50Z (see notifications with IDs 20180601-AL-002 and 20180603-AL-001). The most recent crossing occured at 2018-06-05T14:35Z. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by a high speed stream starting at 2018-05-31T14:11Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2018-06-01T18:50:00-RBE-001.

## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux is above 10^5 pfu starting at 2018-06-01T18:50Z (see notification ID 20180601-AL-002). The electron flux continued to cross the threshold, with the latest crossing at 2018-06-03T14:00Z.

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by a high speed stream starting at 2018-05-31T14:11Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2018-06-01T18:50:00-RBE-001.
